Package Graphics

Class GraphWin

java.lang.Object
Graphics.GraphWin
All Implemented Interfaces:
KeyListener, MouseListener, WindowListener, EventListener
public class GraphWin extends Object implements MouseListener, KeyListener, WindowListener
Represents a window on the screen where graphical images may be drawn.

Creating a GraphWin should generally be the first step taken by any program using this library. For example: 

 
      GraphWin win = new GraphWin("My Window", 600, 600);
This will create a 600 pixel by 600 pixel window

  • Constructor Details

    • GraphWin

      public GraphWin(String title, int width, int height, boolean autoFlush)
      Creates a window for drawing into.
      Parameters:
      title - The window title.
      width - The width of the window in pixels.
      height - The height of the window in pixels.
      autoFlush - If true, the window is redrawn with every move() or undraw() operation.

    • GraphWin

      public GraphWin(String title, int width, int height)
      Creates a window for drawing into, with autoflush set to true.
      Parameters:
      title - The window title.
      width - The width of the window in pixels.
      height - The height of the window in pixels.

    • screenXYtoPoint

      public Point screenXYtoPoint(int x, int y)
      Translates a screen point to user coordinates.

      The transform is set up by calling setCoords.

      Parameters:
      x - The x screen coordinate
      y - The y scrren coordinate
      Returns:
      A Point object representing the corresponding point in user coordinates.

    • pointXYtoScreen

      public Point pointXYtoScreen(Point pt)
      Translates a user coordinate point to screen coordinates.

      The transform is set up by calling setCoords.

      Parameters:
      pt - The Point object to convert to scrren coordinates.
      Returns:
      A java.awt.Point object describing the corresponding screen coordinate point.

      Parameters:

      Returns:
      The corresponding screen coorindate distance.

      Returns an indicator of whether the window is closed.

    • getMouse

      public Point getMouse() throws InterruptedException
      Waits for a mouse click and returns the user-coordinate point where the mouse was clicked.

      I suspect the "proper" way to do this requires using threads, but since this not intended for production use, we should be okay here.

      Returns:
      A Point object representing the user coordinate point where the mouse was clicked, or null if the window is closed.
      Throws:
      InterruptedException - Thrown if the program is interrupted.

    • checkMouse

      public Point checkMouse() throws InterruptedException
      Returns the most recent user-coordinate point clicked, or null if no click has occurred since the last call to getMouse() or checkMouse.

      I suspect the "proper" way to do this requires using threads, but since this not intended for production use, we should be okay here.

      Returns:
      A Point object representing the most recent point clicked, or null if no click has happened since the last call to either getMouse() or checkMouse.
      Throws:
      InterruptedException - Thrown if the program is interrupted.

    • getKey

      public String getKey() throws InterruptedException
      Waits for a key press and returns a String representing the key that was pressed.

      Normal Unicode characters are returned as a single-character String. Special keys (for example, arrow keys) are returned as a descriptive String, such as "uparrow" for the up arrow.

      Returns:
      A String representing the last key pressed, or null if the window was closed.
      Throws:
      InterruptedException - Thrown if the program is interrupted.

    • checkKey

      public String checkKey() throws InterruptedException
      Returns the most recent key pressed, or null if no key press has occurred since the last call to getKey() or checkKey.

      I suspect the "proper" way to do this requires using threads, but since this not intended for production use, we should be okay here.

      Returns:
      A String representing the last key pressed, or null if no key was pressed since the last call to either getKey() or checkKey.
      Throws:
      InterruptedException - Thrown if the program is interrupted.

    • setCoords

      public void setCoords(double xmin, double ymin, double xmax, double ymax)
      Sets up the coordiantes for the window.

      The point (xmin,ymin) is mappeed to the lower-left corner of the window, and the point (xmax,ymax) is mapped to the upper-right corner.

      For example, this call to setCoords(): win.setCoords(-0.1, -0.1, 1.1, 1.1) will set up a window that provides a 1.0x1.0 area with a 0.1 margin all around.

      Parameters:
      xmin - The x coordinate of the point to be mapped to the lower-left corner of the window.
      ymin - The y coordinate of the point to be mapped to the lower-left corner of the window.
      xmax - The x coordinate of the point to be mapped to the upper-right corner of the window.
      ymax - The y coordinate of the point to be mapped to the upper-right corner of the window.
